author: edwint
title: World of Pirates
description: Gamers want to be involved in every aspect of the game they love to play, to have impact in society and to control their in-game assets. [1]

f6_assessments.q0:
I think I am competent to assess this proposal as I have been active in project Catalyst since fund 4 and I have experience analyzing business requirements from over 5 years of delivering software solutions for small business and corporations as well. Aside from that, I’ve been a gamer my entire life and I’ve also worked as a game tester, so I know a bit about the industry.
While the problem statement does not so much identify a problem, as it points out a few things gamers like, we can understand that the proposal aims to create a Free to play and Play to earn game which would give players a lot of control over their in-game assets, allow them to earn NFT’s and also donate to charity. As feedback to the proposer on this part: if you use acronyms in the opening statement of the proposal, explain what the terms means shortly after. Do not expect voters to know these terms as many of them will not be gamers and some will generally not be very tech savvy. Also, later on in the proposal, it is mentioned that the funds here are needed to create the MVP for the game. This should have been mentioned in the solution in my opinion, so as not to confuse people into thinking that the expected output here is the full game.
The short run-down of the project as outlined in the Game Overview section is that it will be a battle royale chess card game (see Might & Magic Chess Royale for a comparison), where people play against each other to earn XP (the use of XP is not detailed), pirate gold (which can be used to buy in-game chests, which, when opened, give you a combination WOPRace tokens, NFT cards or other in-game assets). As far as I understand, these tokens will be used my players, along with WOP tokens (which can only be bought with ADA / fiat) to then vote on the direction of the game in the DAO which will be established later on. The developers also plan to make this game AR compatible to be played outdoors with phones.
I agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge, since what we’re looking for here are good games to bring people in the Cardano ecosystem. I cannot give 5 stars however, because the proposal has not talked about what the success metrics are, nor what the MVP will look like exactly and what the plans to scale in the future are. There are a few words in the white paper about long-term sustainability, but these focus on the fact that the game is Free to Play and are rather vague. I would have expected to see concrete projections for the following months / years.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer has provided a link to the project’s site (https://worldofpirates.io), but it’s kind of empty, to be honest. The names and roles of the 5 team members can be seen in the crew (/contact) section, but these do not provide any information that is not already mentioned in the proposal (role and past experience). Try to add some social links in the future please, so that anyone can verify these are real people easily. I’m sad to say that I personally reported a different proposal here in Ideascale, because it claimed some people worked for them that did not (I reached out to them on LinkedIn and they confirmed it).
Aside from this, another important part that is missing is information on how this project will be completed. We do not have a step by step roadmap, nor a timeline with expected results after 3-6-12 months. Please note that the https://www.worldofpirates.io/roadmap page you point to is blank. You also mention that you have sold some NFT’s and donated them to a charity, but the link you point to for details is also blank: https://www.worldofpirates.io/potm. 
The lack of all this information I presented above, as well as no mention of any possible risks or impediments to the project severely lowers my confidence in the feasibility of the project. 
The only part which has a bit more details is the budget, which is calculated for the following 3 months (how long the proposers consider it will take for them to create the MVP). The numbers here seem credible enough, if a bit high ($4000 per month per developer and 3000 per month per sales person, for a total of $53000 in salaries, while only $1200 is estimated for ads costs). After also adding up the costs with the infrastructure, the total sums up to $60000. Again, these are credible numbers, but a bit high in my opinion for an indie project which is looking to get started. I understand the people in the team have a lot of experience, but you might want to consider looking for extra funding sources as well, since I’m not sure if Catalyst alone can cover all you need from fund to fund.
To recap feasibility, the proposers did not provide links to verify the team’s experience, several links on their site which they refer to are just blank pages, there is no roadmap or timelines except for the mention that the MVP will take 3 months to complete and I feel that the budget is quite high for such a short amount of time for an indie project. Based on the above data, I disagree that this proposal is likely to be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
As described above, the proposal is clear enough in that it wants to create an MVP for a Free to Play battle royale chess card game, but it lacks a lot of details on how it will do that. In the future, please add details about what the approach will be and what the deliverables are at certain intervals (try to think of a timeline for your project with milestones for the 3, 6 and 12 month marks). Also, for projects to be auditable, you need more detailed Key Progress Indicators. At the moment, the proposal only mentions that after going live with your socials pages on 04.12.2021, you got 300 members on Discord, 100 followers on Twitter etc, but Project Catalyst needs to be able to track your progress in the future. For that purpose, it would have helped to set clear targets, like for example: “1000 Twitter followers after a month from the first ad campaign, 60% of minted NFT’s sold after the MVP is released, one youtube video per month tracking the update of the project etc”.
Bottom line, this proposal has a lot of ambition, it seems quite clear from the white paper that the team has put a lot of effort into this idea and I do think that if they managed to get the snowball going they have a shot at success, but lots of important pieces of information that Catalyst needs are missing, as I’ve outlined above. 
At the moment, I neither agree nor disagree that the information here is sufficient to audit the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q1:
The roadmap on the website is great and provides very high level view of the next two years. However for this specific proposal, which is developing an MVP, it is not particularly clear what the steps involved are to achieve the MVP. The proposal really needs a plan vs budget vs deliverables vs milestones to provide confidence in feasibility. At the moment the voter is placing trust in the proposer based on a the website work done to date. This is a simple fix for the proposer, they need to due the due diligence on feasibility and i would suggest they reach out to a project manager/mentor to help with future proposals or presentations to a VC.
A number of people are named in the proposal but it is not clear if these are actually going to be part of the delivery team. In addition resource profiles are not provided in the proposal or on the website.
The is a basic budget breakdown. Senior developer cost of $4000 per month. These are sensible assuming the named resource are simply taking this as their permanent salary and they do not need to engage contract resource which could cost significantly more.
On the basis of what i have seen from the ideafest video only have confidence to give this 3 stars.
There is a note about recruiting marketing and sales people. This is also a key risk to the project. Mitigation is either a very steep learning curve for the current team or a potential increase in costs if they need to engage a 3rd party organisation to help for example.
f6_assessments.q2: Auditability is difficult to assess as not key metrics or KPI's are given. The key question is how can we measure that the MVP is successful? The proposer should think about measuring community feedback on the MVP and develop some targets to check themselves against.

f6_assessments.q0: Firstly, the attached website is very good. It is quite complete, both in terms of content and design. We have a lot of information about the project, and we can get to know it in an attractive way. Now talking about the idea itself: this proposal fits perfectly with the objectives of the challenge. The team intends to create a game that is a mixture of several things: chess, stake pool, NFT and donations to an institution dedicated to activities related to the ocean (here we have the explanation of the name of the game, in addition to the characters, that we can meet in the attached website, being pirates and the game's theme revolve around that). In my opinion, this game has everything to work out, because it already involves something very famous and appreciated - chess - with the minting of NFTs, greatly benefiting the Cardano ecosystem since all this would be done through a pool and also these NFTs could be exchanged for ADA. This would automatically increase the number of transactions on our blockchain, fully matching what we are looking for in the challenge - games that increase ecosystem activities. As a bonus, we could still meet one of Cardano's general objectives, which is to promote sustainability, through the donations made (the authors attach a link that is specifically about this, through which we can better understand this part of the donations). I congratulate the team and hope they are funded.
f6_assessments.q1: 80 years of experience? In this case, the bidders probably added up the years of experience of each one individually to arrive at this number. This did not make me understand the real experience of the group, that is, how old each one is, and in which areas, etc. It is positive, however, that they already have their developers in Plutus, because from what I've noticed many proposals need these professionals but will still hire them. The presentation of the group is perfect - we have a good description of each member, knowing their names, roles and areas of training. The linkedin profiles were also linked, in the end of the proposal. It is also positive how they leave open the possibility of hiring freelancers for design and storytelling areas. That is, in relation to the team, I believe that everything is in order (I was just confused by this story of 80 years of experience). The money asked for funding is also explained very adequately; we know what each small fraction would correspond to for the execution of the project, even though it is a high value (60k) it is quite understandable for the many people who would work here and also the various activities that would take place. It is a large and complex project. The roadmap is attached on a website (https://www.worldofpirates.io/roadmap), I loved the graphic way they organized the steps, really creative and gives us a good understanding of what would be done and in what order. In addition, from what I understand, the idea is to gradually complete the %, that is, in phase 1, they would update: 20% done, 50%... This would even be a way of auditing the proposal, as I will comment on the next topic .
f6_assessments.q2: Through the attached website, we have a well-organized script with a very attractive design. As I was commenting above, with the passage of time they would update how many % of each step had been done, and with that we could monitor the process. However, unfortunately this is the part that is least addressed by the team, because they do not establish KPIs. They don't tell us exactly some goals to be achieved, they don't predict possible challenges to be faced along the way, etc. We weren't helpless, given the great level of detail about what this game is and how it would all work, but I wish the team had paid more attention to how they audited the proposal. I suggest that they review this part, if funded (I hope!) establish ways for the Cardano community to be able to precisely follow, in addition to the development of the project, the partial results that would be obtained.
